g.text: activities refers to participation in organised arts activities
guided by a teacher or other facilitator.
Recent government policies have emphasised the value of maximising the public
gagement in culture and sport and demonstrated a commitment to increasing access to
these sectors. This is evident in both national and regional strategies (e.g.,
are similarly placing great emphasis on increasing and sustaining participation in culture and
The current political climate, strengthened by recommendations from the
and recent events (e.g., Liverpool Capital of Culture 2008; preparations for the 2012
Olympics), provides a genuine opportunity for
maximising public engagement with culture and
The evidence base for engagement in culture and sport has been reviewed by numerous
authors, including projects commissioned by the Department for Culture, Media and Sport
haw, 2004; Freshminds, 2007) and the Scottish Executive
, 2006; Ruiz, 2004). In the literature, many claims have been made about
the impact of the culture and sports sectors on a diverse range of outcomes. These claims,
ased on a variety of types of knowledge/evidence, and reviews of such
knowledge/evidence, having been prepared for different purposes for different audiences, are
not consistent in their approach to gathering, selecting, analysing or quantifying the eviden
here has not been a comprehensive, systematic, consistent cross
sectoral analysis of the impacts of culture and sport.
In England, Arts Council England (ACE) is the national development agency for the arts,
oney from the government and the National Lottery. Between 2008 and
2011, investments will be in excess of Â£1.6 billion. ACE is accountable to the government and
the wider public for the effective use of this public money. As such, it is challenged with
derstanding the values and benefits that such investments accrue to individuals,
communities and society, and with using that understanding to make decisions about the best
use of its resources. As part of a commitment to strengthening the existing evidenc
the impact of the arts, Arts Council England and its equivalent in Scotland, the Scottish Arts
Council, have funded a number of literature reviews in this area (Arts Council England, 2004;
Galloway, 2008; Reeves, 2002), including those looking at
the issues of social exclusion and
The empirical evidence for the impact of the arts
has also been reviewed by Coalter (2001), Guetzkow (2002), McCarthy et al. (2001) and
Newman et al. (2001), and in reviews e
xamining the impact of arts participation in areas such
, 2002; Daykin et al., 2008; Gold et al., 2004, 2009;
Reviews in the field of education have typically focused on children and young people. The
contribution of art education to cultural learning in
, 2006), as has the effects of music instruction on
s reading skills (Standley, 2008). There are two substantial surveys of research on
s of arts participation on children and young people, both conducted
by researchers in the United States. To date, the most systematic and comprehensive
synthesis in the field of arts education is the research conducted by the Reviewing Education
rts Project (REAP), published as a whole issue of the
). A total of 188 relevant studies carried out between 1950 and
1999 were identified and a set of 10 meta
based Arts Education Partnership produced a compendium of arts education
research in which a qualitative commentary was presented on 62 studies (both qualitative and
quantitative research) (Deasy, 2002). These reviews are now quite dated an
reviews are limited either by a focus on a specific sub
